title: Proof

articles.content:
“Proof,” in the full sense, is the process of deriving a conclusion step by
step from the evidence of the senses, each step being taken in accordance with
the laws of logic.
articles.attribution:
Leonard Peikoff, 
Introduction to Logic, Lecture 1

articles.content: “You cannot prove that you exist or that you’re conscious,” they chatter, blanking out the fact that proof presupposes existence, consciousness and a complex chain of knowledge: the existence of something to know, of a consciousness able to know it, and of a knowledge that has learned to distinguish between such concepts as the proved and the unproved.
articles.attribution:
Galt’s Speech,
For the New Intellectual, 154

articles.content:
An axiomatic concept is the identification of a primary fact of reality, which
cannot be analyzed, i.e., reduced to other facts or broken into component
parts. It is implicit in all facts and in all knowledge. It is the
fundamentally given and directly perceived or experienced, which requires no
proof or explanation, but on which all proofs and explanations rest.

acknowledgement:
Leonard Peikoff,
Introduction to Logic, Lecture 1
